contentrichtext.text: [[File:Xerente 1809a.JPG|thumb|right|Xerente Indian]] '''Xerente''' (alternate Sherenté, Xerentes, and Xerénte) are an indigenous people of Brazil specifically [[Tocantins]]. They are a [[Jê languages|Central Jê people]] related to the [[Xavante]]. They maintained generally "peaceful" relations with outsiders from the nineteenth century onward.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=kTUd45or1AEC&pg=PA56&dq=%22xerente&as_brr=3 Indigenous struggle at the heart of Brazil By Seth Garfield, pg 5]</ref> Their villages were traditionally built in a semi-circular fashion, but the society has largely assimilated Brazilian standards of organization.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=x-WilndJnoEC&pg=PA108&dq=%22xerente&as_brr=3 The Attraction of opposites By David Maybury-Lewis, Uri Almagor]</ref> That stated as of 2007 use of the native language among the 1813 members is universal with most being monolingual until age 5.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=dQt6XWloU10C&pg=PA183&dq=%22xerente&as_brr=3 Encyclopedia of the world's endangered languages By Christopher Moseley, pg 183]</ref> == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=xer Ethnologue] [[Category:Indigenous peoples in Brazil]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of Eastern Brazil]]
